claim.text: PICLe consistently outperforms all baselines on three LLMs with respect to Action Consistency.

evidence.exact_quote: PICLe consistently outperforms all baselines on three LLMs with respect to Action Consistency.

claim.text: PICLe achieves an average action consistency of 88.1% on Llama-2, outperforming the current strongest baseline similarity (84.6%) using the same number of in-context examples (K = 3).
claim.exact_quote: PICLe achieves an average action consistency of 88.1% on Llama-2, outperforming the current strongest baseline similarity (84.6%) using the same number of in-context examples (K = 3).

evidence.exact_quote: PICLe achieves an average action consistency of 88.1% on Llama-2, outperforming the current strongest baseline similarity (84.6%) using the same number of in-context examples (K = 3).

claim.text: PICLe helps non-RLHF models, improving performance from 50.1% (base) to 78.6% with only three in-context examples.
claim.exact_quote: PICLe helps non-RLHF models, improving performance from 50.1% (base) to 78.6% with only three in-context examples.

evidence.limitations: Specific to non-RLHF models (Vicuna and GPT-J)

conclusion.key_limitations: Specific to non-RLHF models and K=3

claim.text: Refining the selection pool improves ICL performance significantly, with PICLe[+] achieving the best performance overall (93.1%).

evidence.exact_quote: PICLe[+] achieves the best performance overall (93.1%).

conclusion.key_limitations: Specific to label-aware setting and Llama-2

claim.text: PICLe is robust to the choice of key hyperparameters, with performance not changing significantly with different numbers of epochs.

evidence.exact_quote: PICLe is robust to the choice of key hyperparameters, with performance not changing significantly with different numbers of epochs.

claim.text: PICLe has comparable computational efficiency compared to baseline methods, with a relative 22.6% increase in latency.

evidence.exact_quote: PICLe has comparable computational efficiency compared to baseline methods, with a relative 22.6% increase in latency.

claim.text: Greater distribution changes are required for 'less favorable' personas, with PICLe making smaller distribution changes on 'favorable' personas compared to baselines.

evidence.exact_quote: Greater distribution changes are required for 'less favorable' personas, with PICLe making smaller distribution changes on 'favorable' personas compared to baselines.
